Heritage Line Ginger is NOT a luxurious or premium experience. The marketing and the price make this appear a 5 star experience on paper, but if youre used to luxury hotels then I think youll be disappointed. Were talking 7501000 price point for a 1 night cruise which is a huge amount of money in Vietnam so I expect the best of everything like what Ive got in the top hotels in Vietnam Reverie Saigon, Capella Hanoi, Regent Phu Quoc, Four Season Hoi An etc. The boat looks tired as its clearly not cleaned and maintained properly, presumably as its essentially a work horse where one load of passengers disembark at 10:30, and they then load the next passengers on at 11:45, and this happens day in day out. The rooms are looking tired scuffed walls, broken lamp shades held together by cable ties, poor lighting and they are low standard with low quality sheets, cheap pillows and duvet that are manmade fibres not down, tea and coffee selection is atrocious with the cheapest Lipton bags and very strange flavours like strawberry tea. My room was also meant to come with a bottle of sparking wine but it turned out to be a cheap half bottle of red wine. The hot tub temperature was tepid at best and dirty. The ac unit worked but was filthy with dust. The food was abysmal. They are aiming for fine dining cuisine but clearly the chefs havent been to catering college. The food was so bad that I struggled to eat it and preferred to go hungry. Call me boring, but I also didnt appreciate them pumping out loud club music from 17:15 what penetrated all parts of the boat including our room. I didnt get angry with the staff as clearly they know no better; they clearly havent been trained like what they do in top hotel brands. The staff are lovely though and are clearly trying their best, which in turn makes you feel bad about making a fuss as they simply cant fix the situation as the problems are fundamental and across the board. The tender boat also had quite a significant crash into a fishing boat while transferring us to Ginger. The manager gave some bull about it being because of the currents, but it was plain and simple because the driver was chatting away to his colleagues and not paying attention. The incident could have been very serious, and I was surprised by the complete nonchalant response. We were also given a letter after dinner which included a request for a tip and recommending that 40-50 is typical per room! I could go on and on, but I trust this warns others not to make the same mistake as us booking heritage line. DO NOT BOOK A HERITAGE LINE CRUISE! Ive no idea if theres better cruises out there though. One last word of warning, obviously nothing to do with Heritage Line, but Ha Long Bay is extremely polluted with rubbish and what looks like raw sewage which doesnt exactly wet your appetite when youre being served local seafood. I later read that most of Hanois sewage is pumped untreated into the river which then reaches Ha Long Bag .Read more

The Ylang truly is a luxurious cruise boat with a maximum of only 10 couples on board. The suites are spacious and tastefully decorated. The staff is friendly, always eager to please you... Meals are of excellent quality and well presented.A 20-minute transfer by speedboat from the collecting point to the chain of limestone islets where the moored Ylang was waiting for us; a short welcome by the crew; cabin assignment; briefing and first lunch. It was obvious that this would be a pleasant and well organised trip... We had one of the 40 m2 signature suites with a balcony and a bathroom with tub and spacious walk-in shower - a mixture of classic and modern elegance. Towels were changed twice a day, turndown was done during dinner. Except for the first lunch and breakfast meals were served at the table. You get a sort of order slipand tick your personal choice of courses for the next meal... The highlight of the foody quality meals was the romantic second day dinner served underneath the stars close to the pool area... It is true that we were surrounded by almost 20 other illuminated boats but they all kept their distance and did not trouble us. No idea whether Halong Bay would have been even busier...Fellow guests seem to have enjoyed the kayaking afternoon on day 2 a lot. Other excursions such as biking to some village, going for a short walk on Cat Ba Island and visiting a cave were not that striking. But after all we had come for the view, for the karst scenery, and that is striking!All staff members were pleasant. Ann who had a chat with and a smile for every guest surprised us with a most interesting tea making demonstration. I had never before heard about the blue butterfly pea tea which miraculously changed colour to red when adding honey, ginger and lemon.In total I consider the Ylang cruise a good experience. The ship is first class. Yet, compared to the Jahan cruise on Mekong River we did 3 weeks later the Ylang cruise felt more businesslike - most likely due to the shortness of the trip.Read more

Con tàu Ginger Cruise thật đáng yêu.  Phòng của chúng tôi rất lớn và được trang bị tốt hơn hầu hết các phòng khách sạn.  Nó được trang bị bồn đựng dép, khu vực tiếp khách, giường lớn thoải mái và đồ dùng tuyệt vời.  Tôi yêu con tàu này.  Được bảo trì tốt, rộng rãi với không gian trong nhà và ngoài trời tuyệt vời. Hành trình bao gồm các hoạt động nhưng đây có lẽ là phần yếu nhất của chuyến đi.  Câu mực là một công việc vô ích và thực sự là một công việc quảng cáo.  Thức ăn trông thật tuyệt vời với cách trình bày trực quan tuyệt đẹp.  Tuy nhiên, nó không ngon như vẻ ngoài của nó. Thật dễ chịu nhưng không đáng chú ý. Vì vậy, một điểm trung bình ở đó. Chuyến tham quan làng thực sự khá buồn tẻ.  Những chiếc xe đạp là xe đạp đảo và không có hình dáng đẹp.  Tuy nhiên, chuyến đi qua thung lũng và con đường thật đáng yêu và tôi rất thích điều đó.  Ngôi làng chỉ là một ngôi làng khác ở Việt Nam và thực sự không có mục đích hay điều gì độc đáo ở đó.  Tôi nghĩ nếu bạn có thể nhìn thấy một hang động thì có thể có giá trị tốt hơn. Chuyến chèo thuyền kayak buổi sáng thật ngoạn mục.  Tôi thực sự thích nó và hướng dẫn viên đảm bảo chúng tôi đã lênh đênh trên mặt nước trong một khoảng thời gian dài. We took the Jasmine Cruise and encountered top flight service and cuisine. The manager of the cruise and his staff personally took care of each guest - no matter how small the need. The cuisine is a very successful attempt at fusing or satisfying western and Asian tastes. Local dishes and fish caught same day were served and made all the difference in the taste. Individual dietary needs are perfectly met. At the time of our cruise, the other guests were mostly Brits and some Australians. The boat is an old-fashioned vintage wood type with two floors of rooms and a third common upper deck where bar, dining room and lounge area are located. The activities and excursions are perfectly planned to accommodate individual guest circumstances. There are fun cooking demonstrations, kayaking, hikes, visits to bay villages and oyster farms, but even without them Ha Long Bay is a sight not to be missed.As the only two night stay couple during our cruise, we were treated to an entire day on an elegant day boat, the Sunset, with a staff of four gracious hosts, one who has a BA and MA in English studies and a chef who turned out the most delicious breakfast and lunch. A few areas, some of which could be improved:The bedroom cabins are small, not unusual on this sort of vessel. Knowing the size now, I might have booked the larger cabin on the Violet boat of Heritage line.Tips are a prominent feature and the staff well deserve them, but sometimes there feels a bit of a pressure. It is great that all this can be taken care of at the end.The rooms and bathrooms are a bit tired - showers could be upgraded, and hot water more available. The linens are clean and the beds reasonably comfortable. All in all, the Jasmine was a comfortable and pleasant experience in the mid-range tourist cruise market.Read more

Our two-night Ylang cruise was the final leg of a three-week tour of Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam.  Our previous stop had been Hoi An which had been disappointing due to the crowds of tourists and store after store filled with the same Chinese goods.  I was apprehensive that Ha Long Bay may have been similarly spoiled and had read that the weather in January might be miserable.  Nothing could be further from the truth.  Our Ylang cruise was the absolute highlight of our vacation.Although Ylang has, I think, 10 cabins, there were only two other parties on our cruise. We loved our fellow passengers and immediately felt like we at our own private house party.  I was traveling with my son and had booked one of the less expensive suites for the two of us. Heritage very generously upgraded me to one of the best suites and gave my son his own separate suite.  The suites were huge and very chic and luxurious.  Mine even had a hot tub on the balcony.  I would have been happy to move in for good!The food was phenomenal.  Both lunch and dinner comprised several courses which could be personalized according to diet and preferences.  Everything was fresh and cooked to perfection.  There was an emphasis on healthy eating, but not to the extent that we felt in any way deprived.Our excursions included kayaking, a jungle trek, a cave visit and a visit to a local village and its farm and a cruise through a floating village.  They were all great fun and lead by a delightful guide.  There were also onboard activities, such as a tea class and Tai Chi.  The ship has a spa and we had wonderful complimentary massages.  We did not have much down-time, but when we did, we could just relax with a drink watching the spectacular and it was truly spectacular scenery pass by. The weather was a little overcast but I dont think it detracted from the experience at all.Finally, the service was exemplary.  Do not expect much customer-care ahead of the cruise, but once on board, you will be treated like royalty.Thank you, Ylang, for such a memorable experience.Read more
